s.text: Even so, low income was a risk factor for asthma hospitalization, suggesting that our findings may be more broadly applicable.
Because prior work suggests an unexpectedly high prevalence of aspirin intolerance in persons with near fatal asthma [ 29], we ascertained any history of aspirin sensitivity at baseline interview.
Ecologic studies, based on US census data, have demonstrated a strong inverse relationship between median household income and hospitalization rates for asthma [ 4, 5, 6, 15, 16].
Despite these limitations, we believe the present study results may be generalized to persons with moderate to severe asthma.
Possible total scores range from 0 to 28, with higher scores reflecting more severe asthma.

Because adults with asthma treated by specialists usually have more severe asthma than those treated by generalist physicians [ 25], our study results should be generalized to the overall population of asthmatic persons with caution.
Poor health care access and inadequate preventive asthma care have also been frequently cited as contributing factors [ 5, 12, 13, 14, 15].

Asthma-related morbidity and mortality have risen sharply in the USA since the late 1970s [ 2].
Asthma is a common condition in general medical practice, accounting for about 1% of all ambulatory visits in the USA [ 1].
Systemic corticosteroid use and recent asthma hospitalization, then, appear to drive the relationship between asthma severity and hospitalization for asthma.
Although remote asthma hospitalization did not appear related to risk of ensuing hospitalization, more recent hospitalization was strongly associated with increased risk (OR, 11.
Hispanic race/ethnicity also appeared related to hospitalization (OR, 4.0; 95% CI, 0.9-18.
